column1: Table 5.22: Dominant species found in the natural vegetation in Upper Mahaweli Watershed

column2: Calophyllum walkeri (keena), Palaquium rubiginosum, Michelia nilagirica (wana sapu, kaatu shenbagam), Cinnamomum ovalifolium (wal kurundu, kaatu karuwa), Syzygium spp. Neotitsea fuscata (kudu davula), Adinandra lasiopetala, Mastixia Montana, Gordonia zeylanica (mihiriya), Ilex walkeri, and Elaeocarpus montanus
Actinodaphne spp., Symplocos spp., Syzygium spp., Glochidion pycnocarpum, Acronychia pedunculata and Eurya spp.

Myrsine robusta, Euonymus revolutus, Arundina debilis, Maesa indica, Eurya spp. and Memecylon spp. Psychotria spp., Lasianthus spp.â€™ Rhodomyrtus,Hedyotis spp. Osbeckia spp., Microtropis zeylanica and Berberis spp. Strobilanthes spp. (nelu)
Toddalia asiatica, Elaeagnus latifolia, Piper zeylanica, Smilax zeylanica, Rubus spp.
Exacum walker, (sudu binara), Disporum cantoniense and Arisaema leschenaultia various orchids and ferns.

Lower part of the MWS-010 (1400m and below): The area predominantly consists of small patches and gully forests along streams. No large forests with substantial natural conditions were encountered, so stratification information is unavailable.

Palaquium hinmolpedda, Nothopegia beddomei, Semecarpus nigroviridis, Elaeocarpus glandulifer, Litsea gardneri, Cryptocarya wightiana, Syzygium batadamba, Filicium decipiens
